I was one of those "gifted" kids, having taught myself to read at 4 and read the Laura Ingalls books at 5. However, I started kindergarten at 6 (after one year of preschool). Even with my September 1 birthday, I was by no means the oldest in my class. That's just when kids started school in that district back in the mid 1980s. I really don't think that my mom thought of it as giving me some kind of academic advantage.

My grades were close to perfect until middle school (at which time I dropped back to the "regular gifted" classes), but I was never bored in school. And I certainly was not bored at home for the first five years of my life before starting preschool! We read a lot and didn't watch much TV. To this day, my three siblings and I (with varying degrees of success in school) love to read, are intellectually curious, and enjoy music and other creative endeavors. None of my siblings went to preschool.

My daughter, almost two, has a late August birthday. She is quite tall but pretty average, so far, in terms of social and intellectual development. I had been wondering, until I read this post and all the comments, "Will I send her to kindergarten at 5 or 6?" Imagine my surprise, then, to learn that kids are now starting kindergarten at FOUR. Sending her when she's turning 5 is now practically redshirting!

Childhood seems to be falling by the wayside. A world in which a four-year-old has to sit still and do homework is tragic. Studies have, time and again, shown that kids learn best by playing. Parents who cannot afford childcare should not have to worry that, by putting their kids in school at 4, they are subjecting them to homework and routines they are not ready for. Let 'em play!

As parents, instilling a love of learning in our children is vitally important. Teaching them to conjure a (legal and safe) way out of boredom is equally important. If we do that, our kids are that much closer to being successful in school. Putting four year olds in kindergarten is not the solution.

Of course, since some of the recent comments are all about the blame game, I'll just cut to the chase: the reason why there are so many problems in the public schools is because moms work outside the home, myself included. Shame on me. My poor daughter is now doomed to failure in school, no matter what I do.

What a delightful post! This really takes me back. Toolik is a famous place among field scientists. (It's pretty much the United States' only road-accessible tundra field station, and since the tundra is one of the major ecosystems of the planet, seems like almost every American ecologist goes to Toolik sooner or later.) I was lucky to have five field seasons there myself, working on my dissertation on Arctic birds, with the very same John Wingfield as my advisor.

But, "two days from Manhattan"? Honey, you haven't done the trek till you've spent a full week driving the full 2800 miles on the Dalton Highway from Seattle, through the endless taiga and the endless moose, in a rickety university Chevy Suburban with two dozen Potter traps strapped to the roof and 100 pounds of birdseed bouncing around the back. Then another 400 miles straight north on the Haul Road, getting a flat tire every hundred miles or so, and belatedly realizing you should have brought more than two spare tires. (Also, I swear it was uphill in the snow both ways.)

Seriously though, enjoy that magnificent view of the Brooks sprawling across the horizon, enjoy that eerie midnight sun, enjoy every second at Toolik. And please give my very best to the Lapland longspurs!

Looking forward to more posts!

- Kathleen Hunt (now doing marine biology - but still in love with those Arctic birds. Once a Wingfieldie, always a Wingfieldie.)

I witnessed something similar as an adolescent visiting Moscow in June 1992; a man was beaten to death on the street by a crowd after being accused of stealing from one of the stalls. I have never forgotten the scene, or the rapidity with which a crowd of people who'd been going about the business of living became intent on death. Perhaps most chilling, for me, is what happened afterward, when everyone returned to "normal."

Of course this story and, the video (which I did not watch) are extremely upsetting. This is a horrible story, but one the NYT was absolutely right to cover. It is only by becoming aware of these kinds of events that we might ever begin to have a hope of preventing them.

Meredith, you said:

"Yes, rural families are conservative - it's pretty easy to understand why. Farmers value self reliance, independence, creativity, industriousness, financial integrity, frugality, responsible behavior, and hard work (sun up to sun down, 10-12 months per year); mostly traits incompatible with the gradual but clear socialist path the US is taking."

I would say that these are values that are not unique to conservatives. Nor are all rural families conservative. Growing up amongst both hippie organic farmers and old-time New Englanders in Maine - both socially liberal (on average) groups - these are values that I was raised with. Especially frugality, out of necessity.

I escaped the country as farming was in its last dying throes in my area. But as I've become, more or less, a self-made member of the coastal elite, I still value these values. They've made me a good student at a fancy university, and a good worker in various office jobs. One day, I hope, they'll make me a good professor - the antithesis of the rural farmworker of popular mythology. Assuming that industriousness, frugality, and self-reliance are unique to farm families, and correlate with conservative politics, is not true. In my own experience, these are values that will be as applicable as I attempt to become a professor in the social sciences as they would be if I decided to be a farmer in the rural area where I grew up.

This assumption that good values correlate with rural living is, I believe, part of what people in this conversation may be reacting to when they express scorn for the rural areas of the country. In the myth of America, the countryside is industrious and supports the lazy city folk. We all know that's not true, but it still comes up again and again. It's annoying to everyone, in some way or another. Having lived on "both sides", it's clear that people are people everywhere, under many socioeconomic conditions. Some are hard-working, some aren't; some do great things for their communities, and some are selfish jerks. Assuming a causative, or even correlative, link between certain values and the place you come from is not a productive way for the country to move forward.

Indeed, this was part of the point of the article.
